messages.content: Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Tell me about your experience at DealSourcing.

Dealsourcing was actually a really cool project I got to work on. It's a SaaS based company that gives users real estate analytics for homes all on the market all over the UK. Alacrity had bought the small startup & tasked me with leading the technical acquisition of the company. That means all technical assets were moved over to Alacrity's servers, and I had to make sure everything worked smoothly. Once that was done, I taught myself the codebase and started adding features to the app. I worked alongside a marketing manager, and another jr developper, and under the CTO & CEO. Weekly strategy meetings resulted in a conclusion that the full software should be rewritten. Over a three month period, we redesigned the webpage (in Laravel, HTML & CSS), recreated the database (MySQL, AWS RDS), worked with realtors to create a better algorithm for real estate analysis (python) and connected everythng using PHP.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
What did you do at Alacrity Canada?

Aside from my work with Dealsourcing, I worked with Alacrity as an in-house technical consultant. I helped out with a couple acquisitions on teh technical side. I was tasked with creating new website pages for the company, and worked with the marketing manager to create a new design. I helped set up and troubleshoot different CRM software and helped out with web development for a couple of the in-house companies.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
How's your Python skill?

Python would be my most used dev language, no question. It was the first language I learned in university (about 5 years ago), and I've used it for a variety of projects in different situations ever since. Engineering physics courses require complex mathematical models so I have used a lot of python for class problem sets. This means a LOT of Numpy and Pandas use. All of the AI/ML projects I've done, from my Thesis to the QMIND projects have all been in python. Lots of project experience with packages like TensorFlow, OpenCV and PyTorch. I have done a lot of web scraping work for database aggregation both in projects and for work, so I am very familliar with Scrapy. Finally, my first internship required me to create a beginner python course for high school students and teach it myself. This solidified a strong fundamental knowledge of the language.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Tell me about the ENPH 454 Capstone Project.

I loved this project! It was probably my favourite class from my entire university career. A goup of my fellow engineering physics classmates got together and wanted to come up with an project that required as little physics as possible (we were far more interested in computaing by this point). We bonded over an issue that touched every engineer on campus - the incredibly long wait times for the engineering bar. We came up with the idea of using a point based machine learning model to determine the amount of people in line and from that, calculate the wait time. I chose to spearhead the app development using React Native, creating a user friendly application that would display wait time statistics for the bar with the possibility of expanding to other local bars. I also worked on the point based machine learning model, which ended up having a 90%+ accuracy rate. The best part of the project, though, was spending our Friday class at the bar in order to 'set up the materials' ;).
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
What's your expertise in programming languages?

Python was the first language I ever learned. I have been using it for over 5 years now in a huge number of situations, especially with AI/ML projects. I have lots of Javascript experience, and have used Node.js and React with these projects. A large portion of my work at Dealsourcing was done using Php and the Laravel framework as well. HTML, CSS, C, Java and SQL are all languages I have used in the past, but not as much as the others.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
What inspired you to pursue Engineering Physics with a focus on Computing?

Engineering physics is a bit of a story -- I was originally in science for my first year at Queen's. I hated biology and was really bad at chemistry so physics seemed to be the path to take. I did really like it for my first year but once I joined QMIND, an AI club on campus, I realized that I loved working in teams with engineers. I also found a strong interest in coding. I chose at the end of my second year to transfer into Engineering in order to get more experience with each of those things. I chose engineering physics because I wanted to graduate within 5 years. By the end of my degree, I was far more interested in my computing minor than any of my physics classes. My capstone and thesis were both based solely around programming with little to no relation to physics (sorry Queen's ENPH department). Although I'm very greatful for my experience with physics, I'm very excited to be moving into a career in software engineering.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
How would you explain the concept of 'cooperative perception' to someone unfamiliar with the field?

It is actually i pretty intuitive conecpt. When we think of many of the resons people make mistakes while driving, a lot of it comes down to not enough information about what is happening around them. Is this person going to merge? Is that person going to stop abruptly? What is going on behind that semi truck? All of these predicaments could be solved if we had a hollistic view of the space around us & information and knowledge of the decisions of other vehicles. This is what cooperative perception aims to solve. It allows cars to 'talk to' eachother, exchanging points of view and decisions to be made. This way, a car can know what is happening around it, even if it can't see it. This is especially useful for autonomous vehicles, as it allows them to make decisions based on the information of other vehicles, not just their own sensors. Cooperative perception is not only between cars though, infrastructure surrounding the area as well as satellite information can be used to create a more complete picture of the environment.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Can you describe a challenging moment during your full stack engineering role and how you overcame it?

I think the most challenging part of my role was the fact that for a long time, I was the only developer on the team. This meant that I had to learn the codebase myself, and I had to make all of the technical decisions. I had to learn how to use the AWS servers, how to use the Laravel framework, and how to use the React Native framework. I had to learn how to use the database and how to connect everything together. I had to learn how to use the APIs and how to use the web scraping software. I had to learn how to use the machine learning models and how to use the python packages. I had to learn how to use the CRM software and how to use the analytics software. I had to learn how to use the marketing software and how to use the email software. I had to learn how to use the payment software and how to use the SEO software. All of this was done with the help of stack overflow, youtube, and a lot of trial and error. While it was pretty deficult, I think it was a great learning experience and I'm very proud of the work I did.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
How did you ensure the accuracy and reliability of data scraped using your Python scraper?

I used a couple different methods to ensure the accuracy of the scraping data. Once the base data was scraped, I would run a couple filtering programs to remove outliers. Another program would check for duplicates and a third would check for values that are of the wrong type. I would also check for missing values and fill them with the average values depeding on the other information there is. All these values are to ensure that the data is as clean as possible before it is used in the machine learning model.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Why did you choose PHP and Laravel for the backend structure of the DEALSOURCING website?

When we acquired the original Dealsourcing software, their website was built completely in PHP, Laravel, HTML, CSS, and a tiny bit of jQuerry. Although there was an overhaul of the software, including a substantial redesign of the website, my bosses wanted to keep the same stack.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
What agile development techniques did you find most effective in managing workstreams?

There were two different techniques of agile development that I found to be most valuable for different reasons. A daily standup 'scrum' meeting was incredibly useful to keep everyone on track. Making sure that everyone in the team was on the dame page about developments in the product allowed us to be useful to eachother as well as keeping the project moving forward. The second was continuous delivery. Every task was broken up into small, manageable action items that were easy to deliver. This made me feel like I was contantly accomplishing and finishing tasks whichkept me engaged with the project.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
What was the most challenging aspect of overseeing the technical acquisition for a startup at Alacrity Canada?

There was a lot that was challenging about leading my first technical acquisition. Unfamilliar software languages and programs, lots of new services and responsabilities. I would the the most dificult part overall was getting to know AWS. Its a great service, I know, but god is it friggin confusing. Even just setting up my own RDS took me hours. While I have learned a lot of AWS since, that intiial experience almost had me pulling out my hair.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
How did you prioritize tasks when delivering weekly updates to the board?

The first thing I learned about board meetings is to keep it short and simple. I didn't go into details unless I was asked. Upades were bi-weekly and they covered what was done in the past week, user & finance numbers, and what we are looking to do in the next 2 weeks. This worked well as most of the time they would take this information and suggest tips or alternate paths to get something done.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
What techniques did you use for data analysis when working on the dark matter research?
I used a lot of python for the analysis. Lots of pandas and then exporting that data to use with different modelling softwares.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
What motivated you to teach Python to high school students?

Well it was my job so I kind of had to. The position was a research and outreach intern position. About 25% of the work was outreach and the job I was tasked with was to create a python course that I would teach to highschool students. It was great because I got to hone my funamental python skills and help other students get excited about what I had come to recognize as my passion, programming.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Can you discuss the PointPillar method's significance in feature extraction for autonomous vehicles?

The PointPillar method is a way of extracting features from a point cloud. It is a 3D object detection method that uses a pillar feature extractor to create a 2D bird's eye view of the point cloud. This allows for a more accurate and efficient way of detecting objects in the environment. It is also much more computationally efficient than other methods, which is important for autonomous vehicles as they need to be able to make decisions in real time.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Describe the core functionalities of the 'Queue Hop – AI Line Estimator' app.

Of course! So the app had three main pages. The first would be the home page where it would show a list of containers, each with different bars that would theoretically be a part of our service. Since the camera was only allowed at the engineering bar, the only operational page with accurate times comes from this bar. The list of bars is searchable as well. Once you click on the bar container, it will bring you to a page that details information about the bar, pictures, and information about the wait times including the length of the line in people, the estimated wait time, the amount of people currently inside, etc. These are updated live through a google sheets API that automatically updated readings every minute. The thrid page was your profile page. If we had more time we would have further developed the page so that you could see what lines your friends are waiting in.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
What challenges did you face when integrating the Google Sheets API with the model's data?
Surpisingly there were no challenges faced when integrating the API, luckily it was really straighforward and we were able to get the values quite easily using javascript.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
How would you explain the importance of cooperative perception in autonomous vehicles to a layman?
Cooperative perception allows cars to get a full picture of their surroundings. No blindspots, no suprises. It makes it very easy for the self driving cars to make safe decisions.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Why did you choose JavaScript and React Native for your ENPH 454 capstone project?

I loved this project because of the autonomy I had over the project. I was very interested in trying out react native and I had a bit of experience with JavaScript and since we were looking to create an app, I made the executive decision to use these technilogies that I was specifically interested in. I wasn't super experienced with APIs at the time but a group member suggested google sheets due to its simplicity. It ended up working perfectly!
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
How do you see the future of cooperative perception in the autonomous vehicle industry?

All of the readings I did on cooperative perception (and trust me, there was a LOT) all suggested that if we ever want to see the vast adoption of autonomous vehicles, cooperative perception is a must. It makes the cars safer, more efficient and more reliable. While this year has been big for AV companies (San Fransisco allowing Waymo & Cruise widespread use), the future will require further innovation and infrastructure (both through cooperative perception) to make the safe implementation a possibility around the world.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Discuss a time when you had to adapt quickly to a new software or programming language.

When I was given the rigns at Dealsourcing, I had almost no experience with PHP, or web development in general for that matter. I was completely out of my depths and thrusted into the project. First, I watched a ton of PHP (Laravel specifically) youtube videos to get a handle on what exactly the development process looked like for the stack. I then started combing through the current codebase, trying to learn PHP and Laravel through understanding what each file was doing. When the time came to start making some changes, I relied heavily on stack overflow and references to other parts of the code base to get me through. After about a month I was getting more and more comfortable with the language and development became fun. I still have a ton to learn but I feel that I have a pretty solid grasp on the language and framework now!
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
How do you approach debugging complex software issues?

The most impotant thing to do while debugging is to get a sense of the big picture. What exactly is your code doing. I like to use debugging tools in VSCode (my favourite IDE) to do this. I get to see the path my code takes, what values are equal to what at what time in the program. Once I see this, I am able to see where my program is going awry, and brainstorm how to fix this.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
What are the key considerations when working with large datasets, especially in AWS databases?

I learned in my database program that one of the most important things you can do when working with databases comes at the time of conception. It is incredibly important that I make it architecturally sound with all of the correct relationships defined before ever adding any data. The database should be thought out in a way that makes it easy to add data, easy to access data, and easy to update data. This is especially important when working with large datasets as it can be very difficult to change the structure of the database once it has been created.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Describe your experience working with various stakeholders during your internships.

My first internship was a researh position at the McDonald institute where stakeholders pretty much consisted of my research supervisor and a group of local highschool students that were interested in python. Each were easy to please and allowed a ton of autonomy over the projects I was completing with them in mind. Working at Alacrity Canada, I had a similar experience. The stakeholders for my projects were almost exclusively internal. While I was given less freedom due to constraints given by CEOs, CTOs, and product managers, the majority of the time, I knew exactly what my stakeholders desired and was ale to act upon that knowledge. While I was sometimes working with client facing applications, direction from higher ups was always clear, and I was able to deliver on their expectations. Leading the technical revamp of Dealsourcing was the first instance where I had a lot of potential stakeholders, and needed to seek out their wants and needs for myself. The real estate analytics platform was geared towards realtors, property investors, first time home buyers, and curious home owners. This is a large swath of people, all with different expectations for quality of information, types of features and budgets for SaaS products. Our team had to speak with individuals in each of these groups to best understand how to go about re-development.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Why is database maintenance crucial in a SaaS startup, and how did you approach it?

For many SaaS products the key selling point is the manipulations and analysis that a company has done with their database. People and entities will pay top dollar for useful information, and data allows for the discovery of that information. This means that the database is the most important part of the product. It is crucial that the database is well maintained, well organized, and well protected. I made sure to keep the database as clean as possible, removing duplicates, removing outliers, and removing incorrect values. I also made sure to keep the database as organized as possible, making sure that all of the tables were well defined and that all of the relationships were well defined. Finally, I made sure to keep the database as secure as possible, making sure that only the people who needed access to the database had access to the database. This meant that I had to set up a lot of different user accounts with different levels of access to the database.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
How do you stay updated with the latest advancements in software engineering?

I watch a lot of Youtube. There is a ton of different creators that make high quality videos in the tech news space. Videos about cool new frameworks in a popular coding language, an interesting package that can be used to solve X problem, comparing two different cloud servies to eachother, and the list goes on. It would be humanly impossible to get experience with every new product, language, framework and package that comes out, staying on top of this information and knowing what is out there is the best way to stay up to date with the latest advancements in software engineering. If I see something I think is really cool, I will then try and find a way to use it. Personal projects go a long way to teach you how to develop with new technologies and has changed my relationship and experience to many different technologies drastically.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
What programming projects are you currently working on or planning to start soon?
That's a secret ;). All I can say is that birthdays and holidays are create an important market that hasn't really been tapped into with a quality product yet.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Discuss your experience in utilizing different hosting platforms such as AWS RDS and Heroku.

I won't lie, getting comfortable with AWS, even a single service like RDS took me some time. I had never worked with a cloud platform before and as many people know, AWS is tough starting out. After lots of reading AWS docs, I finally got the RDS set up and could semi-comfortably use the service. On the other hand, Heroku was a breeze. Although I had not used Heroku before, it was very comfortable experience getting to know the platform. I had no issues setting up the database and deploying the app. I would say that Heroku is a great platform for beginners, but AWS is a much more powerful platform that can be used for much more complex projects.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
What excites you most about the future of AI in software engineering?

So much excites me about AI, and so much scares me too. When a lot of people think of AI these days they think of chat-bot LLMs. While I am really interested to see how LLMs continue to fundamentally change the workplace, there is much more out there to be excited about. Using AI in health tech has revolutionized the field and done things that would have never been possible. Education, transportation, and renewable energy are just a few of the fields currently being revolutionized by AI. Though as all things, when there is a force for good, there can also be a force for bad. AI presents a plethera of moral conundrums that too few people motivated by too much money are in the position to weigh in on. Facial recognition software seeks to de-aunonomize the world with everyone's digital footprint one face search away. The velocity at which AI could take over jobs in the next 20 years could create a 'useless class' of global workers with no skills an AI couldn't quicker for cheaper. Even something as seemingly harmless as the technology used to create a fake drake song has the possibility to be used to create a hyper realistic video of politicialns, militants, or terrorists saying and doing things that never happened. I'll leave it to you to think of the reprocussions that could ensue. AI is a double edged sword, able to bring society into a new age to technological matruity, but also able to corrupt and destabalize the world as we know it.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
How do you handle constructive criticism, especially regarding your code or software solutions?

Constructive criticism is an incredibly important part of both completing a project and progressing in your career. It is very important, as any kind of employee, to take constructive criticism well. Because I have been had a job pretty consistenly since I was 14 years old, I have had to take a lot of criticism in my time from employers and customers alike. I have learned to deal with this very well. When I am criticized, usually constructively, I listen carefully to what the people say. I want to make sure that I am totally understanding what criticisms they are putting on me. Then, if I find something unfair or untrue, I will voice that respectfully. If I find something that I agree with, I will thank them for their input and make sure to take it into consideration in the future. I think that constructive criticism is a great way to learn and grow, and I am always open to it.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Describe a time when you took a proactive approach to solve a challenge before it became a bigger problem.

When I was working at Alacrity, I was helping out one of the portfolio companies with their web design when I noticed that the website was not responsive. I knew that this would be a problem for the company as more and more people are using their phones to access the internet. I took it upon myself to make the website responsive, and I did so in a way that would not affect the current design of the website. I did this by creating a new CSS file that would only be used when the website was being accessed on a mobile device. This way, the website would still look the same on a computer, but would be responsive on a phone. I was very proud of this solution, and the company was very happy with the result.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
How do you envision the role of software engineering evolving in the next 5 years?

I think that as we have seen in the past year with the emergence of large language models like chat-GPT, software engineering will become much more efficient. Paired programming with AI will allow for much faster development and bug fixing, leading to much more efficient workers. I believe that although there will be some automation. Many people are worried that AI will take over the jobs of software engineers, but I think that it will just make them more efficient. I think that software engineers will be able to do more in less time, and will be able to create more complex and interesting projects. I think that software engineering will become a much more important part of our society, and will be used to solve many of the problems that we are facing today. Climate change is a massive issue at the forefront of people's minds today. I hope the green-tech revolution continues and engineers are able to create and contribute to ideas that will help us save our planet.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
How do you handle situations where you're unfamiliar with a particular technology or tool required for a project?

This has been a common theme in my software development journey. Whether I was helping out with a new protfolio company or starting a personal project, there was always a new language, framework or technology that I had to learn. I have become very comofrtable diving into these projects. While the exact methodology may change depending on the type of software I am learning, there is a similar path throughout. I will always start by watching ideos on Youtube of people talking about the software. This always gives me a good understanding of what I can expect. I will then usually follow a small to mid length tutorial to learn the basics and best practices of the software. This can be building a simple webpage, setting up a user database, creating a simple algorithm or walking through a type of cloud software. While completing this initial task, I will regularly consult with the documentation of the software & related forums to get a better understanding of what I am doing. Following this step, I will apply the software more generally to a project that I am looking to use it for, continuing to consult documentation & forums as my use cases are usually more complex than the tutorials. This is the general process I use to learn new software, and I have found it to be very effective. Time constraints have definitely changed the process depending on the project, but this is the general process I use to learn new software.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
What strategies do you employ to ensure clear communication with non-technical stakeholders?

My experience as a teaching assistant for a quantum physics class has really helped my ability to communicate complex topics in very simple terms. I have found that the best way to communicate with non-technical stakeholders is to use analogies. I will often compare the software to something that they are familiar with. For example, I might compare a database to a filing cabinet, or a server to a warehouse. I will also try to use as little technical jargon as possible. I will try to explain things in a way that anyone can understand, even if they have no technical background. I will also try to use visual aids whenever possible. I will often draw diagrams or pictures to help explain what I am talking about. I have found that this is the best way to communicate with non-technical stakeholders, and I have had a lot of success with this method. An important part of this would be to always make sure that the people you are explaining to understand before you move on. If they aren't getting it, switch your analogy, or find a different way to explain it. It is important that everyone is on the same page, and that everyone understands what is going on.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
How do you manage and optimize the performance of SQL databases?

Optomization is a really important part of successfully maintaining your database. My typical method is to start by making sure that the database is well organized. I will make sure that all of the tables are well defined, and that all of the relationships are well defined. I will also make sure that all of the data is clean. I will remove duplicates, remove outliers, and remove incorrect values. I will also make sure that the database is well protected. I will make sure that only the people who need access to the database have access to the database. I will set up different user accounts with different levels of access to the database. Really large databases can lead to latency in access so if needed, I will use caching when obtaining these values.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Can you describe a time when you significantly improved the efficiency of a piece of software or system?

When I was working at Dealsourcing, the original code was incresibly slow, especially when accessing data. I set out to create a REST API with endpoints at various databases and tables for optimal calling time. Once these were designed, I implemented them into the website. To increase effectiveness, I used caching and optimized querries so that speed was at the forefront of the design. Doing this, I increased website speed by 200% and server response time by 95%.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Discuss a moment when you felt particularly proud of a software solution you developed.

When I had finally finished the Dealsourcing software overhaul and we got to launch the beta, I felt incredibly happy about the massive amount of time that I spent working on this product. Seeing it come to fruition was the most rewarding part.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
How do you handle tight deadlines, especially when facing unforeseen challenges?

This is a very important part of working as an engineer. There have been many times that I have made the mistake of giving a tight timeframe and ending up running into many issues. Other times I have just been given way to tight of a timeframe to finish a project. I have found that the most important thing you can do when it comes to these situations is to communicate clearly. If you do that, people will always be more understanding if they are not blindsided by issues.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Describe your ideal team environment for software development.

My ideal team environment is a group of 5-6 engineers who are passionate about their projects and happy to help eachother out when needed. It is so important that a team can lift eachother up and help eachother grow as engineers. Speaking of growing as an engineer, I would also love a team lead that is further along in their career and can offer me advice and guidance when needed. I would also love to have a product manager that is able to communicate with the team and the stakeholders to make sure that everyone is on the same page. I would also love to have a designer that can help with the UI/UX of the product. I think that this is the ideal team environment for software development, and I would love to be a part of a team like this.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
Can you describe the process and tools you used to develop your portfolio pages? How did you ensure they effectively showcased your technical skills and accomplishments?

Since my current portfolio was a mimic of chapt-GPT, the formatting of my answers was pretty easy since I knew exactly what it would look like. The dificult part came in actually trying to write code that made it look like a typewriter while formatting the paragrpahs correctly scrolling with the typing. The easiest part was coming up with the text as I had it from a previous portfolio!
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.
What were some challenges you faced while developing your portfolio and how did you overcome them? Were there any specific projects or achievements you felt were particularly important to highlight?

I faced multiple challenges with this protfolio. one of the first was learning how to use tailwind CSS. Since I was used to classical CSS and Sass, it was a bit of a different experience getting used to this kind of styling, but after some practice, I have fallen in love with it! Another issue I ran into was formatting the response querries while having the ability to autotype them out. This took me a while to figure out and I ended up hardcoding the styling based on what type of element they were. If it was a header, it would have its own class, a picture from the QueueHop app would be a seperate class. This would allow me to insert these elements in the correct order with the correct styling while keeping the ability to have the autotyping feature that is consistent with chat-GPT.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.

In your involvement with the AI club on campus, what kind of projects or initiatives did you spearhead or contribute to? How did this experience further your understanding and application of AI concepts?

When I was at QMIND I was involved int wo large AI projects as well as an executive position as Director of Professional Development. The first project was my first coding project ever and it made me fall in love with the development process and working as an engineering team. This project I worked on was called helping hand and we used object detection to create a model that would recognize ASL letters, We then built a mebpage with camera access that would detect and translate these letters in real time. At the Canadian Undergraduate Conference in AI, we won best paper. In my second project I was able to take more of a leadership role as I was the most experienced with coding at that point. We chose to scrape years worth of twitter data with the hashtag tesla and apply sentiment analysis to it. We then used this data, as well as bloogmberg stock dta to create a predictive model of the stock price for the company based on the sentiment of the tweets that were sent the day prior. This was a really cool project where I got lots of experience with data collection and aggregation as well as machine learning. Finally, I worked as the Director of Professional Development where I was in charge of organizing workshops and events for the club. I was able to learn a lot about event planning and organization as well as how to communicate with different stakeholders to make sure that everyone was on the same page. Throughout the yer, I hostel multiple panels with tech industry professionals. These panels achieved the highest trunout (by far) for any event that year and I was very proud of that.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.

Collaboration is often key in both software development and AI research. How did working with the AI club on campus help you improve your teamwork and communication skills, especially in a technical context?

Before joining QMIND, I had never really worked on a tehnical team before. Sports, sure, group projects, sure, but this was a real development team with a group of engineers. We met for an hour eery week and contributed ideas, learned from eachother and contributed to the project. This is where I was introduced to both agile development and github, two things that would stick with me throughout my career. Looking back, this experience was the main reason that I switched into engineering. I wanted to continue to be able to vuild those relationships with other engineers through group work.
Griffin is a new grad young professional experienced in software engineering and physics.

Considering your experiences from both developing your portfolio and engaging with the AI club, how do you believe these experiences have prepared you for future roles in software engineering and AI-related fields?

While these experiences play a part in preparing me for roles, expecially since they were the foundation of my career, I wouldn't say they they are the biggest factors that have prepared me for my professiona career. During my time with the McDonald instuitute, I leveraged python skills used in QMIND to create a far more complex mathematical models of galaxies. I then used this experience to secure a position with Alacrity, which gave me the sharpest learning curve of my life. I was able to learn so much about software development, AWS, and web development in general. I was able to take these skills and apply them to my capstone project and thesis, which was a great way to end my degree.
